disobedience.question: Was I disobedient to my parents?

disobedience.question: Did you reject the unity of the Church when struggling to understand or relate to others within it due to their imperfections?
disobedience.description: Rejecting Church unity due to frustration with individuals is sinful because it confuses the Church's divine nature and eternal truths with the human imperfections of its members, while also violating Christ's prayer "that they may all be one."

disobedience.question: Have I rejected the unity of the Catholic Church when frustrated by disagreements or misunderstandings within the community?

disobedience.question: Did I condone a funeral where human remains were not buried, thus disrespecting the dignity of the deceased?
disobedience.description: Failing to advocate for proper burial of human remains is considered sinful as the Church teaches that the body is sacred and deserves reverent burial, with scattering or keeping remains being contrary to the dignity of the human body and resurrection belief.

disobedience.question: Did I ridicule the Church?
disobedience.description: Mocking the church shows contempt for Christ's established institution on earth, disrespects the Body of Christ, and undermines the Church's divine authority as guided by the Holy Spirit.

scandal.question: Did I intentionally lead someone to commit a sinful act through my deeds?
scandal.description: Leading others to sin (also called "scandal") is sinful because it actively harms another person's soul by encouraging them away from God, making you spiritually responsible both for your own sin and for potentially damaging another's relationship with God.

autonomy.question: Did you take for granted the good things in your life, forgetting to acknowledge their source in God's providence?
